I thought this place was most typical S.F tourist type restaurant  a bit rip off place, but it wasn't that bad actually.
We came here twice. once for dinner, once for lunch.
We tried not to come here when we see a line. Yes, this place gets hectic sometimes. But when it's open, this place is Good for a couple, it is romantic especially early evening. Well, I like early evening North Beach and Fisherman's wharf.
There is clean and pretty dining area. We had nice and professional service. 

I live S.F more than quoter century but I still get asked that I am tourist even though I never wear shorts, jogging shoes and socks! I don't hold camera either.
author: Nobu K.

description:
I knew better and yet still did it. And I paid the price by having to eat the bad food. The focaccia they bring is dry and worse than store bought. The entrees were so uninspiring that I think it took me an extra five minutes to decide what I wanted. Some of the sauces were too salty, others bland. It was definitely a weird mix of bad tastes. 

The service was good and my water glass was never empty. Then again, the place was relatively empty so it's not like the waitstaff had to strain themselves. Oh, and the host cancelled my OT reservation instead of confirming and I lost out on points.
author: The Sock S.

description:
My review is based on a "take-out" order that I made on a Saturday evening. 

I was down to get a "table for one" - this place looked so nice I don't think I would have cared if I was dining alone or not - but it was SO packed, I would have had to wait an hour. The atmosphere was awesome. I loved the decor. The staff was super friendly. I got a plate "to go" and was surprised that I didn't have to wait that long. The bartender was amazing as he handled the whole entire restaurant, patio and bar by himself with ease. Now the food.....OH MY! Was it good. I had seabass crusted with pistachios, garlic mashed potatoes (the creamiest ever) and asparagus spears. The packaged it all up and gave me enough bread to feed an army. YUM!
author: Jewel N.

description:
I was walking to Trader Joes and realized that I should really not go in there on an empty stomach, so I ended up here (it was either this or fast food and I am NOT eating at Burger King).

The waiter, who thought he was exceptionally cool wearing sunglasses indoors, was loud and rather obnoxious and made a big deal out of the fact that I wanted iced tea with lunch and not something from the bar. A) I drank way too much the night before, and B) kiss my ass! Maybe the pushy used-car salesman thing works with the tourists, but as far as I'm concerned all you are doing is knocking percentage points off of your tip.

The breadservice was foccacia. Not like real Italian foccacia, but then again it was not as bad as the stuff they sell at Safeway. It wasn't crispy and chewy, but soft and was completely bereft of oil and salt on the top. Yeah, so it had decent flavor for "bread" but the little Italian ladies in my family would be horrified that such stuff was being passed off as our beloved foccacia.

The antipasto plate turned out to be a hodge-podge of blanched vegetables (broccoli, green beans, wax beans, cauliflower, onion, bell peppers, onions, mushrooms and a little fennel) and a little shredded domestic proscuitto, a couple slices of salame and a little shaved, young (read: cheap) parmesan. the plate was drizzled with a fake balsamic that is a caramel colored sugar syrup (no, really). This is just cheap and lazy cooking. How about grilling the vegetables and including some nice cherry peppers and fresh mozarella? And skip the balsamic, real or otherwise. A nice drizzle of quality extra virgin and a sprinkle of sea salt would have been perfect.

For my main course I had the Fettuccine Frutti ai Mare, since I looked the waiter straight in the eye (or at least where I thought his eyes were behind his sunglasses) and and asked him if the crab ravioli were frozen (they were). As it turned out the dish is sort of a re-envisioning of cioppino turned into a pasta dish, which is actually not a bad thing at all. The tomato sauce was a tiny bit spicy and somewhat rich and was definitely the best thing about the dish. The mussels, clams and salmon all seemed fresh, but the shrimp were cooked to the point of being hard and crumbly - completely inedible. The pasta was cooked just short of being al dente, but I'll take undercooked rather than overcooked any day.

I doubt I'll ever go here again. I mean really, how lazy do you have to be to totally screw up an antipasto plate? I think two stars is pretty generous. Save this place for the tourists.
author: Thomas S.

description: Price was reasonable if you are stuck in the Fisherman's Wharf area a little off the strip. Food was basic boring Italian nothing special but acceptable. Wouldn't rush back but provides sustenance. I had spaghetti Bolognaise OK, sone had meatballs OK, daughter had chicken Picatta boring but edible. Etc etc anyway wouldn't go again
author: Christopher W.

description: Way overpriced, small portions, food not nearly worth the price.  Gets two stars only because my son loved the spaghetti.
author: JD B.

description: So I was in SF over the weekend and in walking distance from this place, it looked pretty busy and smelled good from the outside. My wife and I ordered 2 different pizzas and our freinds ordered other stuff (dont remember!). Everything looked very nice, the food was cooked well and it looks like they use fresh ingredients (not frozen) but the taste was another story........ everyone said the food was bland, flavorless and I agreed. I think that my share was about $120 for 2 small pizzas and 2 captain and cokes once the 18% gratuity was automatically included in the price. I was expecting a lot more for what I paid. I would definately not go back in this place again. The 2 stars is for the nice waitress and the nice looking dishes.
author: Aldo O.

description:
Must Try:

1.Mozzarella Alla Griglia - grilled fresh mozzarella. Mmmm.. the best appetizer ever! 
2.Branzino Allo Zafferano - roasted seabass w/ pinenut crust cooked to perfection!
3.Pollo Al Marsala - tender chicken w/ delicious garlic whipped potatoes, mushrooms in a yummy sauce.
4. Ravioli Con Granchio - just the right amount of crab meat filled inside. I like to dip mine in the sauce before my first bite, and second and third bites (if there was a second and third bite left that is..).

The spicy Italian sausage is delicious as well =)
And for dessert.. the panna cotta is my #1 pick. But the chocolate tort and the pear bread pudding are following very close behind (depending on my mood)!

MENTION TO YOUR SERVER THAT YOU'RE A LOCAL, AND YOU'LL GET 10% OFF YOUR BILL!
author: Elaine H.

description: Food was o.k.  Service was some of the worst I've ever had.  There were 3 of us for breakfast around 10:30 on a Sat. (only because we were staying at the attached hotel), and the place was mostly empty.  One person ordered a mimosa and a water, and the other 2 simply ordered waters.  The person who got the mimosa did not get his water.  No big deal; we'll just ask again later.  When our food came, he requested a water again.  No water ever came.  No one ever stopped by our table to ask how the food was or if we needed anything else.  I ended up going to get a water pitcher myself so I could refill our glasses.  Our waiter seemed to have disappeared somewhere along the way.  The food was not bad, but overpriced for the quality.  I had to work really hard to flag down someone for our bill.  At that point we should have just left without paying.  I will not be back here.
author: Leah A.

description:
So I come here as a local, a lot! Say 3 or 4 times a week. Why? 

Can't beet the tomato soup (polenta on the bottom of the bowl) and the focaccia bread. My daily lunch comes out $4.95 and I am full. 

Other recommendations: The polenta dish; comes with pesto, marinara, and cheese. The pizza on a good day. As I said, I come here a lot. It's 3 blocks from where I work, attentive service, and good food. 

The pizza story: A friend of mine had ordered a pizza here twice before and it was disgusting, burned in parts and raw in others. How do you even do that?

This one day I was craving pizza so I decided to give it a shot. I tell the waiter what I want, and then to my own shock, out of my mouth comes "can you keep an eye on it and make sure it doesn't suck." I am not the kind of person who usually says/does things like this. That same friend is with me and decides to try the pizza again. The result. Divine pizza, perfectly thin crust, right amount of cheese and toppings. 

Why not 5 stars? I come here all. the. time. and the waiter (Carlos) still gives me a menu and wine glasses. Now, don't we know each other better than that by now?
author: Julia D.

description:
An experience at this restuarant...FRESH!

Crab Ravioli, Calamari, and Sea Baa - so FRESH, all tasted like it was straight off of the boat. I would recommend these dishes to anyone.

Service - Definitely a breath of fresh air in comparison to some of the more stuffy place. Simply lovely.

Clientele - Fresh because it is always changing. It is attached to a hotel so there are lot of tourists. 

Atmosphere - A great place to have an outdoor glass of wine on a fresh spring day.

Recommendations: Make a reservation on Open Table to avoid a wait.
author: Aubrey W.

description: I thought the service was a little rushed and the drink list was better on paper than at the restaurant. I had a grilled pizza. It was okay, not great. Definitely pricier than the menu and the flavor profiles deserve.
author: Lauren R.

description: We went here for breakfast and probably because it was morning the service was really slow (our server was nice and polite though). Food was ok - in general it was delicious but because of the slow service it came to us a bit cold. In general french toast and homemade granola - delicious, crab benedict - ok.
author: Ksenia Z.

description: My wife and I were in San Francisco our our anniversary, and we found this little neighborhood gem on Restaurant.com. The reviews were great, so we decided to try it. It was wonderful! The food was great, the service was great, and the ambiance was just perfectly quaint. I would definitely recommend this place!
author: Bryan J.

description:
11/6/08: Lunch with former co-worker. First visit here, I arrived right at noon and pleasantly surprised that the lunch crowd was a light. While near fisherman's wharf, the overall neighborhood was quiet, clearly a sign of the slower economy - I was expecting something much worse.  We opted for indoor seating and settled near a booth next to a service counter that opened up to the kitchen.  I ordered the zuppa di pomodoro, a tomato soup served with polenta (on the bottom) and big dop of parmesan cheese and fresh parsely on top.  polenta was different, never had in a soup. served a little mushy inorder to work in a soup and very creative.  Second plate was their mixed salad with gorgonzola cheese and walnuts, that wasn't anything extraordinary and did not disappoint.

restaurant is part of the Tuscan Inn.
author: Jesse W.

description: I was a little hesitant about this place because of the mediocre reviews. I stumbled upon them because I had a $25 restaurant.com credit and figured why not. It turned out to be really lovely. To start off I had their Manhattan which was smooth and has amazing brandied cherries. We had the Bruchetta which had a nice balsamic punch to it and the tomatoes were very fresh. After the app the chef dropped by with a special treat, a single shrimp in a cream sauce. I thought it was such a nice touch and I was really impressed by it. For my entree I had the crab ravioli which was in a cream sauce and topped with leeks. It was quite good and well seasoned. My husband had the seabass and it was on whipped potatoes that were so creamy and delicious. The customer service was impeccable from the hostess who checked on us after seating us to our waiter who was very attentive. I look forward to going back.
author: Adrienne P.

description: Dined here while visiting SF. It's location is perfect,near hotels and Fishermans wharf.  I expected alot better since I thought this looked to be one of the "non touristy" places we could eat at near our hotel.  Atmosphere and ambience were great, so was service.  Food.....not so much.  This was the blandest Italian food I've ever eaten.  The chicken parmigiana was OK, but the sauce for the spaghetti tasted like Ragu, except with less flavor.  I ordered a pasta dish that was edible but lacking any real flavor.  The kids mac-n-cheese was like they poured milk over some cooked pasta.  My 8yr old said "where's the cheese"?  That pretty much summed it up. Felt bad for our server because he was really trying to make it a good experience--the meal just fell flat.  The executive chef needs a lesson on Italian cooking!  Don't waste your money
author: Mari W.

description: I don't go to the wharf, but for my girlfriend who likes this place I said sure why not. I can see why she likes it. Lovely atmosphere, great service and food. It is quite reasonable, granted we shared everything but still in my book rather cheap. All of this without the tourist craze, I would go back.
author: Natasha M.

description:
The service was fast and friendly. We sat outside since the weather was cooperating and requested they turn the heater on for us.  We only had time for a quick meal so ordered just the calamari appetizer and the margherita pizza to share between the 2 of us.  The food arrived quickly and together, which worked for us so that was great.  

The calamari, though tasty, was a bit on the soggy side.  Not crispy at all on the breading.  The margherita pizza was hot, cheese was melty and the crust was crunchy.  Fabulous. Yum. we devoured it. 

Downside to this restaurant is the extravagant prices.  Since they are in the touristy part of town, i can see why..but really? $30 entrees?! 

At least the pizza was affordable. =)
author: Lulu C.

description: The best part of our experience (besides the good food) was seeing how well the staff worked together. The service at this restaurant was excellent and everyone was friendly and very helpful.
author: David G.

description: Came here for pizza and a salad before a big halloween party and wasn't impressed.  we got the spinach and onion pizza which was actually pretty good by my pizza snob standards, but the salad was only mediocre and not very big.  for the price, i dont think i would come back here.  they do have what looked like a wood burning oven, though, so might be worth another try.
author: Lisa C.

description: I  just had a very odd dining experience at this restaurant. Was it me, or was the waiter following a script? Nothing that came out of his mouth sounded natural and I heard him using the same monologue on the table behind me. He would only address me as "the lady," and by the second, "would the lady like more water?" I was ready to snap. On top of the annoying dialogue there was hot pink lipstick on my wine glass (I had zero make up on), the soup and wine tasted severely watered down, the pizza was raw and the Cesar salad consisted of one giant piece of iceberg lettuce. Stay far far away....
author: Kathleen E.

description:
The boyfriend and I were in San Francisco over President's Day weekend. Our flight into SFO was delayed by two hours (due to fog, go figure!) so by the time we made it to our hotel we were famished! We stayed at the Best Western Tuscan Inn and Cafe Pescatore is located on the corner of the hotel. We were too hungry to Yelp it first so we decided to take a risk and try it. He ordered the chicken parm and I had the crab ravioli. My ravioli were ok, nothing to rave about as I thought they could use a bit more salt. The b/f wasn't crazy about his chicken parm either. We decided to skip dessert and opted for some Ben and Jerry's that we found while walking along the piers.

Because we were staying at the Tuscan Inn, we were eligible for the Happy Hour specials. Come to think of it, this might be open to everyone. I'm honestly not sure. Anyway, our hotel offered a free wine tasting which we decided to take advantage of one night. After having our free glass of wine, we decided to do Happy Hour at Cafe Pescatore. We paired our ice cold (exactly how they should be!) Blue Moons with some crab cakes. These were way better than the bland food we had for lunch during the beginning of our stay. And we kept getting free focaccia bread which was an added plus in my book. My second visit to Cafe Pescatore was definitely better than my first although I did notice the bar tender somehow forgot to charge us happy hour rates as some yelpers had mentioned. We made sure he corrected that! I wouldn't necessarily dine here again but would def come back from the free bread, crab cakes and the ice cold beers!
author: Ivonne M.

description: I organized a family dinner here this past Monday for 12 people. It was sort of a last minute get together, so I appreciate that the manager (Nick) at Cafe Pescatore, was able to work with me and he set up our table in a secluded corner at the back of the restaurant. Service was prompt and efficient. Our dishes came out in a timely manner. Hubby and I shared a seafood antipasti appetizer and their rib eye steak. It tasted ok, but nothing spectacular. I tried my sister's lamb shank and I liked how it was fell off the bone tender.  Overall, it was a good experience for my family and we left satisfied and full. It definitely helped that I found a $100 dining certificate via restaurant.com, so that made our total bill a lot less than expected. Would definitely give it another try if I got another certificate.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
We were a large group with reservations for brunch/lunch. The food was fine, although nothing special. The service was very poor, with requests for water, tea, etc. repeated several times. The breakfast menu was not offered, even though the hours indicate that on weekends breakfast is served til 2. The dessert menu was not offered. We had to ask for everything.
 It was as if it was our waiter's first day on the job; he was pleasant but clueless and no one else working there helped him out. It seemed as if no one was in charge and no one cared. 
  I know this restaurant can and does do better than this.
author: P R.

description: Wow... One of the worst experience I've ever had... Not only was their waiter who was the manager on shift incompetent but a liar... Either that or he spoke little to no English... It was Monday today so it was happy hour all day according to their menu... We got 4 appetizers and 4 drinks... It should have come out to 55 dollars... 5 dollar appetizers and 7 dollar drinks... Well they charged us 90 dollars... Each time we pointed to their special menu the waiter asked where we got the idea... To which we pointed their menu... The waiter just nodded... Why have a special all day happy hour on Monday if u don't adhere to it... Now we don't mind paying 200 for food but if that's what it said we won't complain... But if you're going to say 5 dollars appetizers and 7 dollar drinks and charge 10 and 15 respectively then youre a pathetic business owner and should not run a business... Sad... Avoid this place at all cost... Spend 150 at the house on north beach and enjoy it... This place is a travesty...
author: Nathan D.

description: Very nice place. Good atmosphere and excellent pizza.  Handmade and fresh.  Tiramisu was awesome and enough to share.
author: Kathy O.

description:
I never get tired of this place, LOVE breakfast, lunch and dinners. 
never disappointed, Bryan, Rosario and "Ruthie" are Superb.....and the chef is the coolest chefs ever....  
Thank you Pescatore 
...Pescatore one of the BEST restaurants in the Whar'f
author: hugo v.

description: As a local, I tend to stay away from Pier 39 and Fisherman's Wharf area when looking for a place to grab some good food and drinks, on the basis that everything I've tried in the area has been a disappointment.! Pescatore' has always been a favorite hidden gem, located just a couple blocks up from the wharf! With a great ambiance, delicious  food and an extended happy hour with drinks and food for locals,I've always been overly satisfied each time I've visited. The staff is always extremely friendly, out going and attentive! Will continue to visit whenever  I am in the area!
author: Rosé O.

description: I love dinners at Pescatore!  The sizzling platter of garlic prawns and mussels in amazing.  The ribeye is grilled to perfection and the pastas are delicious as well.
author: Amy D.

description: By far the worst meal had while visiting San Francisco.  Went there for dinner after arriving to town late on a Friday night - it was accessible and close, but a bad choice.  Calamari was overcooked and tasted like it was cooked in old oil.  Cioppino was overcooked and too salty.  Branzino (which menu describes as Sea Bass) tasted like bad cod - also overcooked and not flavorful.  Pizza was OK.  Can't recommend this place.
author: Thomas T.

description: The boyfriend and I came here for a nice dinner on his birthday, had read pretty good reviews on tripadvisor.  The location is nice, close to fisherman's wharf, and the restaurant looked very cute with a nice atmosphere.  The service was not great and the food was BLAND.  Both our salads were mediocre at best.  I ordered the sea bass which was dry, overcooked, and bland, while my boyfriend had the seared ahi, which was a decent piece of fish completely drenched in a disgusting mustard sauce.  We were terribly disappointed.  Please save yourself from this overpriced restaurant.
author: Syneva D.

description: I have been at the Tuscan Inn all week and totally enjoyed the atmosphere and the bartenders.  The food  is great and the service is amazing.  It felt like home.
author: Janet B.

description: Excellent restaurant in the wharf area, but a few streets off the main. We were there for dinner. Atmosphere, menu, service and food all are excellent. Pasta dishes, seafood, and more. We ordered Branzino al Zafferano (roasted seabass) and the Chicken Marsala. Beautiful presentation, portions that were not too large or too small, and very flavorful. Recommend the restaurant and these dishes.
author: Julie W.

description: Food was good but service was absolutely atrocious. Came in for dinner by myself on a Monday night. I spent 20 total minutes eating and 1 hour sitting idle waiting for my server. This seemed to be the case in the whole restaurant. If you need to make that Alcatraz cruise at a certain time, definitely do not eat here.
author: Aamer A.

description: A bit overpriced, 30 for a ciopinno!  Service stunk, maybe because we were eating outside.  Had to take our water glasses inside and request a fill up.  When our entrees were delivered, mine was not in the order, they forgot it.  It took about another 20 minutes to get my entree, about 10 minutes after everyone else in my party finished eating.  I dropped a fork and they brought me a new one and told me not to let it touch the table because the tables are pretty dirty.  The other food was just ok.  Probably will never go there again as the service was really horrible, I felt, like I was a nuisance to them as they seemed frustrated with our normal requests like, more water, some bread, etc.  if you go I recommend you eat inside at a "clean" table.  There are much better Italian style dining in the area the area with better prices and much better service who will appreciate your business.  Solicit businesses that care.
author: Master B.

description: Brought my boyfriends mom in after a day of shopping and doing the touristy thing. As a life long local I was impressed with the cocktail menu, good wine list and great menu. It's hard to find great food on the wharf, but Pescatore is definitely it. Very attentive service that made the bf's mom feel special, and delicious crab ravioli for me. If you go make sure to try their Caesar, when done right it is a great salad and it is done well. Nice big pieces of anchovy, not too much dressing and beautiful large shavings of parm.
author: Caroline B.

description: After the Aloha Festival my bf and I wanted some dessert, we ended up looking for road side parking right next to Cafe Pescatore. Btw, the parking meters are a total rip off! $3.00 for an hour? Why can't people just park for free on Sunday...jeeez! Anyway we both had a cappuccino which was pretty decent, I had the tiramisu and he had the chocolate tort. I thought the tiramisu was a bit dried, but the chocolate tort was delicious. Excellent service, the waiter was very friendly...after we left I forgot my camera on the table and he chased us down and returned it. How sweet!!
author: Afakasi Teine A.

description:
We went to this place last weekend. I had a cousin in town who was staying at the Sheraton and this cafe being really close we decided to go there. The staff was extremely rude and unfriendly. The food was average and this is not the place to order mojitos!
I would never go back again.
author: Jiggy B.

description: Food was okay... Chicken Parm, recommended by the waitress, was supposed to come with a spicy marinara but it was a bland, chunky tomato sauce.  Pasta was overcooked but chicken was okay.  Nothing to write home about.  No spoons for twirling the pasta, not sure how've"Italian" this place really is.  The service was absolutely horrible, they would never make it if they had to rely on "regulars" instead of the tourist trade.
author: Mel N.

description: The food was bland, overcooked and the service was slow.
author: Shaun D.

description: Great fried calimari and nice dirty martinis. On wednesday they have a special dog menu. Bring your dog, sit outside, and treat him/her to their very own menu of dog-friendly food. Note: This place is highly populated by tourists (due to the location), but the open air atmosphere is great on a nice day...
author: Nicolas H.

description:
Since I happened to see it listed in my restaurant guide earlier AND there was parking in front, we decided to try it.  The dining room was welcoming and so was the bar. While being seated at a table in the middle of the dining room, I asked if we could sit in the vacant booth across the way instead. The answer was no because it was being saved for when the restaurant got more crowded. Well, another couple was sitting in a booth. Not fair.  

Anyway, the mista was a little bland, just like my trusty little book had said. I should have listened. Oh well. The steak and pasta special (both recommended by our waiter) made up for it. The pear bread pudding was also good, but tasted a lot like the raisin French toast that I had for breakfast that morning. 

Verdict: Unexpectedly delightful.
author: Nicole N.

description: Terrible service. I understand it was a busy Wednesday night, but for the 19% gratuity that they get, they however ignored our table most times and an hour's dinner turned into more than 2 hours in this restaurant. The food wasn't that great either. The dungeness crab ravioli was hard and undercooked. It's definitely a tourist trap, and I recommend driving somewhere else for a comparable price.
author: K B.

description:
I was in the area and keep forgetting to leave my review. It was recommended at the hotel I was staying at. 

The service was great and the food was delicous. If I'm in San Fran, I will most likely return. 

Great selection of wine by the glass.
author: Iris F.

description: My husband and I had dinner at Cafe Pescatore last night.  I thought it was a lovely restaurant with lots of charm.  The staff was friendly, and the waitress was very sweet and informative. We started with the skillet roasted seafood antipasti.  It  contained prawns, mussels, and clams roasted in a delicious garlic and oil sauce.  Next we had the sea bass coated in roasted pine nuts in a saffron sauce.  We substituted fettucine for the mashed potatoes, and we enjoyed it very much.  I would have liked more of the saffron flavor in the sauce, but overall the large portion of sea bass tasted fresh and was perfectly cooked.  Dessert was a chocolate lava cake with gelato ice cream.  Yum.  We also had a specialty coffee, as it was a special deal on Thursday nights. I found the prices to be reasonable for the quality of food.  We have a place nearby, and we will definitely have lunch or dinner here again.  It's a little treasure in our neighborhood.
author: Christine S.

description:
My rating is higher than others, probably because:

1. We had a large group but everything came out quickly
2. We were headed to a show after eating and were just grabbing a quick bite so there wasn't a lot of room to disappoint (i.e. no seared tuna.)
3. (and most importantly) I was stressed when I got there, ordered a Pinot Grigio which came out with a quickness, and taking into account #2, (thank you light mixed green salad) I was much more relaxed by the time I left!
author: A W.

description: I have to admit i had very low expectations going in as we chose it pretty much based on the fact it was close to our hotel. However, we left extremely satisfied! We had a Calaramari salad, several pasta dishes and a four-cheese pizza. It was all really good! It was a bit pricey but what isn't in this town? Very pleasant and professional service added up to a definite solid find. I would easliy go there again and again..and probably will!
author: Glen D.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco! The ambience is lovely, the food delicious (the pastas and desserts especially) and the service first-rate. I've never had a bad experience here. And it has a great wine list!
author: Nikki G.

description: This restaurant was surprisingly not too bad for a hotel restaurant, especially one at a Best Western! Our flight was late coming in from Oakland, and we didn't want to venture too far the first night. We decided on Pescatore. My mom and I shared a pizza with truffle oil, mushrooms and pancetta. I loved how the restaurant had a wood-burning pizza oven! It made for a tasty pizza. The truffle oil was a nice touch too. We also had breakfast here a couple mornings, nothing special, but nothing horrible either. Prices were reasonable for a hotel restaurant.
author: Amy C.

description: Bit surprised by this place.  Thought, "Oh god, this is going to be all tourists" and it wasn't!  Hostess was a bit confused it seemed but our waiter was awesome and very attentive.  Food was good (not great) but overall good.
author: Lauren R.

description:
This place has decent service, good decor, but the food left something to be desired.  The chocolate tort was by far the best, with the table focaccia coming in second.  

We had the bruschetta, "pasta special," and the aforementioned tort.

Our waiter was friendly and service was prompt but overall the food was just much too bland.  For the price, there are much better meals to be had nearby.
author: Tony C.

description: There is nothing special about this place, save for the spotlessly clean white tablecloths. It reminds me of the places in Amsterdam along the tourist paths where aproned sleazebags lure you in with pomp and gloss and the promise of an 'authentic' Italian meal. Well, it's not that bad, but it's not that good, either. I will say that the service is polite and attentive. Go with someone who is paying, if you go at all.
author: Jabe N.

description: Bland food.  Not worth the money.  You're better off eating at the pier.  I will not eat here again.
author: Stefanie L.

description: This is a little Italian restaurant that is on Fisherman's Wharf. It is away from the Italian restaurants in North Beach, but this is a real find. The place was packed with people and the decor is warm and inviting. The service was very good. Try the fish special on the menu and the Polenta, because it was outstanding. I would definitely recommend it as a place worth visiting
author: Belinda w.

description: We went with a group of ten and the service was relaxed but there when you wanted it. I have to admit I wasn't crazy about my crab ravioli - it was cold and the pasta undercooked (I do like al dente) and the sauce was way too strong with basil, which I usually like but this was overpowering. BUT the other people at the table loved the caesar salad, lamb, chicken marsala & prawn dishes. Maybe I just ordered the wrong thing - there were also a couple of pizzas that looked good. We were happy that they let us linger with out of town friends who were staying at a nearby hotel. We were never rushed and enjoyed the atmosphere. The bathrooms are far - through the lobby and down the hall by the conference rooms, but space is certainly at a premium in SF. I will try it once again, but not the ravioli.
author: Theresa C.

description:
This review is for breakfast only.  The only reason we ate here was because it was right in our hotel, wrong move!

The breakfast menu was unimpressive, it didn't even have French toast which is what my son wanted so he settled on pancakes which was okay, nothing special.  If you don't mind having a standard every day breakfast then this might be okay for you.  For me and my family, we enjoy when restaurants offer some sort of special menu item,  it was dissappointing.  

The service could have been better, we had to signal the waiter a couple of times for coffee refills.  

Nothing special.
author: Sunny D.

description: okay I was waiting for my son to get his job at the ILWU union hall. i waited and waited for him. to my surprise he showed up with this big bag and says to me "hey Mom, want some fried calamari?" im like what??? I opened the box and there they were.. all fried up (even the lemons) with horseradish  and chilli sauce( in separate cups of course!) then another box with some foccacia bread squares. I LUV fried calamari...I mean LOVE... did I say I LOVE calamari fried. and this..uh hummm was hella good!!! good to know they have take out too! hella good..I would attempt to fry my own but just cant stand looking at all those legs/arms/squiggly attached things ...truth be told.. I dont cook anything that scaares the shit outta me...but hell I WILL eat em!! nuff said...
author: Jay E.

description: On a whim, and partly because I've been trying to buy a cool Alcatraz Water Polo shirt (don't ask), my friend and I decided to head up to Fisherman's Wharf for a lazy brunch. At first, our options seemed limited to Buena Vista Cafe and Hooters, but then we happened upon Pescatore Cafe. The place was relatively busy, mostly with elderly tourists, so we were seated promptly at a nice booth. I went with the French Toast, which I'd recommend and my friend went with a sausage and mushroom omelette, yum! Our server and the manager were very nice, very attentive, perhaps because we were the only people who seemed close to their ages! A surprise post-breakfast experience is getting some free coffee at the adjoining Best Western. You can sit in the lobby, or by the fireplace, watch bedazzled and frumpy tourists ask about how to get to the Wax Museum or H&M, or you can bother the concierge yourself, asking him some inane questions only people who call our city "San Fran" or "Frisco" would ask. Good stuff.
author: Nish N.

description: The restaurant is connected to the hotel we stayed in down by the wharf so we decided to check it out. The staff was super friendly and the bartender became a sort of friend to my boyfriend who ended up visiting the bar every nught we stayed there. The cook made my steak rare on accident instead of well done and to make up for it sent out a complimentray dessert. When I say this dessert was fantastic, I mean it was FANTATSIC. It was some kind of Italian custard with a berry wine glaze and fresh berries. OMG! It was so good! And really sweet of the cook. The creamed spinach and mashed potatoes that came with my steak were really delicious, too. My boyfriend and his dad got the dungeness crab ravioli...so good!
author: Tina L.

description: Love the decor and the plethora of windows.  The table was ready when we got there even though we were late.  The food was good as well.  Definitely will come back if we are in the area.
author: Enoch S.

description: The service was good and the staff was nice.  We ordered the Ravioli and the Linguini.  Both were extremely bland and so overpriced for what we got.  We also ordered a pair of Bloody Mary's.  The Bloody Mary's were sort of like a V8 with some tabasco.  After having Bloody Mary's at Cioppino's it was a definite step down.  I am still unsure if any alcohol actually entered the glasses.  On the plus side, it was open late, and the espresso was good.  Other than that, we would have been better at spending our $80!!! somewhere else.
author: A G.

description: Went there with my parents to visit my brother, and since it was a bit away from the Fisherman's Wharf and below our hotel, we stepped in.  Place is nice and clean, decor decent.  I'll have to give credit to our waitress as she tried to give us good service, but our food came in late and service in general was suffering but it was not her fault - they were understaffed due to sick personnel (they stayed home, of course).  With that aside, my parents and brother enjoyed their pasta dishes as they thought it was tasty.  Mine, on the other hand, was not - it was a nightmare.  Since I didn't want any "corrections" or whatever as they had staffing issues, I ate it any ways - my dish was not tasty, in fact, it seemed if it was made tasteless, was missing the chicken in it, totally not what I like and what a good risotto dish should be.  Totally a bad culinary experience in my book.  Though I did make mention of my bad meal to the waitress and she seemed a bit upset by it (hey, I am not going to lie about a bad meal), but I did tip her well despite all that's happened.  I'll give this place one more try before putting it in my ban list.
author: Y.D. K.

description: honestly?  this place is good.  surprised?  i was too!  don't be scared of its proximity to all the tourists...it's so well worth a try.  so try it.  and if i were you, i'd stick with the fish dishes (pinenut-encrusted sea bass is killer), calamari and desserts (tiramisu is bomb-diggity).  the pasta dishes are just ok.
author: Adela K.
